content: The Act may be cited as the "Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act". In the 10 years from 1987 through 1996, nearly 2,200 children in the United States aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings. The US leads in rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death. The United States has the highest rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death among industrialized countries, with a rate 9 times greater than 25 other countries combined. Nearly 8 times the number of children who die from unintentional firearms-related deaths are treated in hospitals annually. The rate of unintentional deaths from firearms for children under 15 in the United States is 9 times higher than in 25 other industrialized countries combined. Additionally, nearly 8 times more children are treated annually in US hospital emergency rooms for nonfatal unintentional gunshot wounds. In the United States, children as young as 3 years old are strong enough to fire most commercially available handguns, as found in a study published in the December 1995 issue of the Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine. A study in California found that unintentional gunshot wounds in children often involve handguns. Children as young as 3 years old have enough finger strength to fire most commercially available handguns. Firearms in the US are not subject to minimum safety regulations. According to a study, children as young as 3 years old have sufficient finger strength to fire the majority of commonly available handguns. Firearms in the United States are not held to minimum safety standards, despite 74% of the population supporting safety regulations for the firearms industry. A 1997 poll found that 74% of Americans support safety regulations for the firearms industry, as firearms and safety locks involved in interstate commerce may not always prevent accidental discharge. The standard required by subsection (b) shall be issued within 12 months and take effect 6 months after issuance. Test protocols from section 1700.20 of title 16, Code of Federal Regulations, related to poison prevention packaging standards will be considered. SEC. 4. ORDERS; INSPECTIONS. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of handgun discharge protection products that violate the Act. They can also require the recall, repair, or replacement of such products. The Secretary may issue an order requiring the manufacturer of a handgun discharge protection product to provide notice of risks to the public and dealers if the product violates the Act. The Act requires manufacturers to provide notice of product risks to the public and dealers, ensure product compliance with regulations, repair or replace the product if necessary. The Act requires manufacturers to ensure product compliance with regulations by taking various actions such as repairing, replacing, refunding, recalling, or submitting a plan to the Secretary. The Act mandates manufacturers to ensure product compliance by taking actions such as refunding the purchase price, recalling the product, or submitting a plan to the Secretary for implementation. The Secretary may conduct inspections to verify compliance with the Act and its regulations. The Secretary may inspect places where handgun discharge protection products are manufactured, stored, or transported for commercial purposes to ensure compliance with the Act and its regulations. SEC. 5. UNLAWFUL ACTS. Beginning 30 days after a final standard is issued, it will be illegal for licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers to sell handguns without a handgun discharge protection product that meets the standard. An exception is made for sales to government departments or agencies. Licensed dealers are prohibited from selling handguns without a handgun discharge protection product supplied by the manufacturer or importer, with an exception for sales to government departments or agencies. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. In accordance with SEC. 6, handguns must include warning labels on packaging and descriptive materials, with a specific statement in conspicuous type. Handguns must have warning labels on packaging and materials, with a statement about preventing child access due to the risk of severe injuries or death. The warning label required for handguns must be in contrast with other printed matter on the package or descriptive materials, similar to regulations in effect as of January 1, 1998. Additionally, handguns cannot be sold without accompanying packaging or descriptive materials. The warning label must be affixed to handguns when transferred without packaging, as per regulations in effect as of January 1, 1998. This section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers must report any information indicating a child's injury or death from a handgun sold after the Act's effective date. SEC. 8. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary can impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for each violation of the Act, revoke a federal firearms license for violations, and allow private individuals to take legal action for violations. Private individuals can bring a civil action in a US district court for damages, including attorney's fees, against anyone who violates the Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act or its regulations. Private individuals can bring a civil action in a US district court for damages, including attorney's fees, against anyone who violates the Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act or its regulations. The remedy provided in this paragraph is in addition to any other remedy under common law or Federal/State law. Private individuals can bring a civil action in a US district court to enforce the Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act, with the possibility of receiving attorney's fees as part of the costs. This remedy is in addition to any other remedies available under common law or Federal/State law. Compliance with this Act is irrelevant in determining private remedies. In a civil action under the Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act, the court may award attorney's fees to the prevailing plaintiff. Compliance with the Act does not exempt liability under common law or State statutory law. The Act or any regulation under it does not exempt liability under common law or State statutory law. The Secretary's failure to take action authorized by the Act is not admissible in litigation. Criminal penalties apply for violations of the Act or regulations regarding handguns. Under this Act, evidence of non-action by the Secretary is not admissible in litigation. Criminal penalties apply for knowingly violating provisions of the Act or regulations related to handgun discharge protection products, including fines and imprisonment up to 2 years. SEC. 9. NO EFFECT ON STATE LAW. This Act does not override State laws unless they conflict with it, and State laws providing greater protection to children regarding handguns are not considered inconsistent with this Act. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms such as "handgun discharge protection product" as a device designed to prevent unintentional handgun discharge, "children" as individuals under 18 years old, and other terms related to firearms as per section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code.
